This line will print 1 - the remainder of integer division (5 / 2). The remainder operation % has to be applied to integer numbers and its result is integer.

lines.line: /*  Example max2 - maximum of two values
Goal: demonstrate the use of if-else

lines.comment: This is a prompt
This scanf statement gets two integers separated by a blank from the user and placed them into variables a and b.
This statement prints the first part of the message. At that time it is not clear which of the two values is a maximum

This if conditional statement has expression a < b in its condition. If a is really less than b, the value of the expression will be 1 and "then" part will be executed. Otherwise, the value will be 0 and "else" part will work
This "then" statement will be executed if a is less than b and thus the condition value is 1. That means that b is the largest of the two numbers
This "else" statement will be executed if a is greater of equal b and thus the condition value is 0. That means that a is the maximum of the two numbers

lines.line: /*  Example max1 - maximum of two values
Goal: demonstrate the use of if

lines.comment: This is a prompt
This scanf statement gets two integers separated by a blank from the user and placed them into variables a and b
This is a pre-assignment. We make a hypothesis that a is the maximum and pre-assign max to a
Our original hypothesis can be wrong. Here we are checking this case - maybe a is really less than b? If it is true, then the value of (a < b) is 1 and "then" statement will be executed.
This "then" statement will be executed if a is really less than b. In that case b is the maximun, our hypothesis was wrong and we need to correct the situation assigning max to b
Nothing has to be done if (a < b) is false. In that case max is already pre-assigned correctly. So, we are using if-then form of if.

lines.line: printf("Maximum of %d and %d is %d", a, b, max);
lines.comment: Whatever is the maximum value, it is now assigned to the variable max. We simply print its value for maximum.
This is the end of the main function body

lines.line: Goal: The use of if-else for conditional calculations

lines.comment: This scanf statement gets two floating point numbers separated by a blank from the user, processes then using %f specifications and places them into variables rate1 and rate2.
We read a floating point value into a floating point variable capital using %f specification
The goal of the conititional statement below is to decide which of the two rates has to be used in our case to calculate interest. The correct value will be assigned to the variable interest_rate
If capital is less than THRESHOLD, the value of capital < THRESHOLD expression will be 1 and "then" part of if will be executed.
This is the "then" part of if - in this part interest_rate will be assigned to rate1 (lower of the two)
If the condition is false, i.e., the capital is greater or equal to the THRESHOLD, the value of capital < THRESHOLD expression will be 0 and "else" part of if will be executed.
This is the "else" part of if - in this part interest_rate will be assigned to rate2 (higher of the two)

lines.line:
printf("The rate for $%.2f is %.2f%%
", capital, interest_rate);

", annual_interest, capital + annual_interest);

lines.line: Goal: The use of if statement inside the loop
Reads numbers until -1 is entered. Prints the max number entered.
lines.comment: The semantic interpretation of this program is funding out the size of the largest group coming to the party.
This time we will use -1 as a signal to stor calculation. Since a group of -1 people can't come to a party, it is a good sentinel value.
variable max will be used to store the "running"" max value - i.e., the max of the values read so far.
This is the usual pre-reading statement
Since we have so far only one number read, it is also the max of all read numbers
This is a sentinel reading loop. It will work until nexnumber (value read from he user) become equal to sentinel - here -1
If the newly read number is greater that thhe current max, then it is the new current maximum and we need to store it in variable max
This line re-assigns max to the new maximum value if the condition above is true.
This line reads new value from the user. It is a part of sentinel reading pattern
After the sentinel value is read and the loop stopped, the variable max stores the maximum of all read values. So, it is printed.

lines.line: /*  Example max3 - maximum of three values
Goal: demonstrate the use of nested if

lines.comment: This is a prompt
This scanf statement gets three integers separated by a blank from the user and placed them into variables a, b and c.

lines.line: printf("Maximum of %d, %d and %d is ", a, b, c);
lines.comment: This statement prints the first part of the message. At that time it is not clear which of the three values is a maximum

This if conditional statement has expression a > b in its condition. If a is really greater than b, the value of the expression will be 1 and "then" part will be executed. Otherwise, the value will be 0 and "else" part will work
This is then part of is. As long as we are there, we know that a > b (i.e, b can't be max), but we still need to check whether a > c to find the absolute max.
This is then part of the first inner if. If we get there, both a > b and a > c were true, so we can report a as the max
This is else part of the first inner if. If we get there, then a > b was true, but a > c was false. I.e., c >= a while a > c. So, we report c as max.
This is else part of top level if. As long as we are there, we know that a <= b (i.e, a can't be max), but we still need to check whether b > c to find the absolute max.
This is then part of the second inner if. If we get there, then a > b was false, but b > c was true, so we can report b as the max
This is else part of the second inner if. If we get there, both a > b and b > c were false, so c >= b and b >= a. We can report b as the max
To use getchar() we need this standard library. EOF constant is also defined there.
nc is defined as long since we want to process large files by input redirection
as a typical counter, nc is initialized to 0 before the loop. It is a part of counting pattern.
Function getchar() is executed each time we check this condition. It always return either next character from the input stream or a special value EOF (End of File).
The counter is incremented every iteration of the loop. So, at the end it will tell how many times the loop was executed.

We exit from the loop as soon as getchar() returns EOF. EOF is not processed in the loop.  Since we read exactly one character per loop iteration the number of characters read is the number of iteractions - counted by nc.

lines.line: Print some printable characters with their codes

lines.comment: This is the lower bound. Characters will be printed starting with the blank character
Loop running variable is being assigned to the lower bound of the table. This is a part of th table processing pattern
This is a typical table-printing loop with FIRSTCHAR and LASTCHAR for the upper and lower bounds and step 1. The loop will be executed while the running variable c is under the upper table bound.

This is the main statement in the loop body. We print the current value of char variable c both as a character and as an integer (through casting). The integer value of a character is known as its code. So, a code table is printed.

Characters are internally represented by character codes that are small integers. Increment and decrement, addition, subtraction can be used. These operation will turn c into a char with next code (a to b, 4 to 5, etc.)
This is the end of while loop body
The stdio.h header file is required if we use getchar() and putchar() functions. EOF constant is also defined there.
Variable c is defined as integer since EOF value that it can get is not one of 256 values that a char variable can get. Variable nl is a counter of lines.
As any counter variable, nl should be initialized to zero before the counting loop. This is a part of the counting pattern.
This is a sentinel-controlled loop. Current symbol (or EOF) returned by getchar() is assigned to variable C. If the assigned value is not EOF (End of File), we will proceed to the loop body.

The idea of line counting is simple. Each line ends with 
 symbol. So, by counting 
 symbols, we will count the number of lines. This condition is true if c is a newline symbol

If c is a newline symbol 
 we will increment the new line counter nl. Thus we will count all newline synbols
This is the first statement after the loop. It simply prints the number of lines counted.

Lines that begin with # are preprocessing directives. Include directive commands the preprocessor  to include headers of input/output functions so that you program can access such functions as getchar and putchar.
This defines the main function of your program and it is required once and only once in your program. Main returns a value of type  int and has no parmeters.
Variable c has been declared as an int type.  c is represented as an int because the EOF value cannot be a char.

getchar is a c function found in the stdio.h library that takes the keyboard input value and places it to the variable c.  Even though c is an int, this is  legal because an int can take all char values. The input value given to c is tested to see if it i
putchar() is a c function found in the stdio.h library that writes characters to the screen, in this case, c.
Since main is declared as an int function, we return an integer value. Traditionally returning 0  tells the operating system  that the program was completed OK.

This is a preprocessor command. System header file stdio.h will be   inserted there during compilationWe include stdio.h header file because it contains function   prototypes for getchar and putchar and a definition of symbolic   constant EOF

lines.line: /*       Sort list using Insertion Sort. The list is divided into
sorted and unsorted list. With each pass, first element
in unsorted list is inserted into sorted list.
Pre  list must contain at least one element.
last contains index to last element in the list

lines.comment: When first called from main, this function begins with the first value...
...and keeps track of the last index, which is here 14, since there are 15 positions.
Appropriate names are given to each variable, enabling easier human tracking of how the sort works.
The outer loop continues through the list from beginning to end.  Current gives the indexes from 1 to the end.
"Hold" contains the value of the current position.
"Walker" is the index to the left of current.    At first, it starts at zero, when current is 1 (the first two left values are compared).
The For loop continues as long as the index "walker" doesn't become negative and "hold" is less than the value to it's left.  This means it's out of order.
Notice this is a parens ')' and NOT a }, because it closes the For loop expressions.
Beginning  block of inner For loop statement.  It is executed only if the conditions about walker and hold are met above.
This block is executed as long as the two values are out of order.  The first line switches values.  List[walker + 1] is really just "hold".
Walker continues to the left:  one is subtracted from it each time (decrement).
End of nested For loop block.
After the inner loop is run, the value of hold is put into the position    list [walker + 1].
Wherever walker stops, give one position to its right the value of hold.
During each outer loop, current is incremented.
No value is returned because it is a void function.  However, it is done sorting!
End of "insertionSort" function.
The comment contains the expected results.

lines.line: /* Sorts list[1ast] by selecting smallest element in
unsorted portion of array and exchanging it with element
at the beginning of the unsorted list.
Pre     list must contain at least one item.
last contains index to last element in the list
Post   The list has been rearranged smallest to largest

lines.comment: Once again, the sort takes an array--
--and the INDEX to the last element.
Once again, we go through every position.  Current is an index value.
Start with "smallest" being the value of the index current (initially that's zero).
Comparing it to the position to its right--
-- as long as walker doesn't go beyond the far right element.
Walker goes one more to the right.
This If statement is nested inside the For loop.  It does the actual comparing.
If the "walker" position is smaller than the known "smallest" position, this index will now become the new "smallest"
The current value is assigned to a temporary variable.
The smallest value is assigned to the current position.
The smallest value is now replaced with the former current value.
End of For loop that traverses the list, using current as an index.
This continues through each position, putting the smallest value at the beginning of each ever-shorter (unsorted) list.
